The receipt, storage and conveyance of anhydrous ammonia is the single highly hazardous process present at the Santee Cooper Winyah Generating Station (WGS) facility.  This determination is based upon federal and state process safety management (PSM) regulations and Santee Cooper standards.  This process (receipt, storage, and conveyance) is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68 which addresses the potential off-site hazards of accidental releases.



The EPA Risk Management Regulation identifies three program levels (1,2, & 3) of requirements.  Program Level 1 is applicable to a process for which it can be demonstrated that no public receptors (e.g., residence, parks and recreation areas, commercial/industrial facility, hospitals) would be affected by a worst-case release.  A covered process is subject to Program 2 requirements if it does not meet the eligibility requirements of either Program 1 or 3.  Therefore, Santee Cooper's worst-case scenario identifies public receptors that would be affected.  40 CFR Part 68 identifies that the processes at the Santee Cooper WGS facility are subject to Program 3 requirements.  The Santee Cooper Accident Prevention Program elements are adopted directly from the compliance program for the PSM standard, consistent with the Level 3 RMP Program requirements for this facility under 40 CFR Part 68.



Covered Process and Description of Ammonia Storage and Handling

The only RMP-listed toxic chemical and covered process that is present at the Winyah Generating Station is anhydrous ammonia and the process consists of the following areas:



►    Ammonia Unloading - Offload liquid ammonia from truck trailer into eight ammonia tanks 

►    Ammonia Storage - Store liquid ammonia in eight ammonia storage tanks

►    Ammonia Feed to Selective Catalytic Recovery (SCR) unit - deliver liquid ammonia from ammonia tanks to SCR for reaction with NOx.



The location of the ammonia storage tanks was determined to be 33.32617? Latitude, -79.354

557? Longitude (NAD 83: Zone 13N) using ArcGIS, converted to decimal degrees using http://www.rcn.montana.edu/Resources/Converter.aspx. This location was used in the MARPLOT software as the center point for the release radius.



Modeling Software and Selection

For the 2021 RMP update, ALOHA 5.4.7 and MARPLOT 5.1.1 were used. A number of release models were evaluated in order to identity a model that would provide a reasonable evaluation of the release scenario and properties of anhydrous ammonia in the atmosphere for the conditions at WGS. The following models were evaluated:



DEGADIS - The Dense Gas Dispersion Model (DEGADIS) is a mathematical dispersion model that can be used to model the transport of toxic chemical releases into the atmosphere. Its range of applicability includes continuous, instantaneous, finite duration, and time- variant releases; negatively-buoyant and neutrally-buoyant releases; ground-level, low-momentum area releases; ground-level or elevated upwardly-directed stack releases of gases or aerosols. 



SLAB - The SLAB model is capable of simulating a dense gas release from a ground level evaporating pool, an elevated horizontal jet, a stack or elevated vertical jet, or an instantaneous volume source. Sources may be part vapor and part liquid droplets; except the evaporating pool source which is assumed to be all vapors. 



AFTOX - The Air Force Toxic Chemical Dispersion (AFTOX) model is a Gaussian dispersion model that is used to calculate toxic corridors in case of accidental releases. It is limited to non-dense gases. It can directly calculate the evaporation rate from liquid spills. AFTOX treats instantaneous or continuous releases from any elevation and can calculate the rise of buoyant plumes. It is intended to be consistent with the ADAM model for passive (neutrally buoyant) gas releases. 



ALOHA - The Areal Locations of Hazardous Atmospheres (ALOHA) system was developed jointly by NOAA and EPA. ALOHA can model toxic gas clouds,

flammable gas clouds, BLEVEs (Boiling Liquid Expanding Vapor Explosions), jet fires, pool fires, and vapor cloud explosions. 



The conditions of the ammonia release result in a two-phase release - liquid and vapor. Therefore, the release considered a dense gas release. AFTOX is not suitable for a dense gas release; therefore, DEGADIS and SLAB were evaluated. Technical problems were encountered with both models. The DEGADIS model was unable to represent the two-phase release. The SLAB model did not have the capability to model the tank release without representing it as a vertical jet, which resulted in an unrealistic scenario. 



ALOHA version 5.4.7 was used to model the release. The Heavy Gas dispersion calculations used in ALOHA are based on the DEGADIS model. Some simplifications were introduced into ALOHA-DEGADIS, making it different from the DEGADIS model. ALOHA-DEGADIS is limited to releases at ground level and does not account for the initial momentum from a jet release. Some of the numerical methods used in ALOHA-DEGADIS have been simplified compared to those used in DEGADIS. 



Selection of the Worst-Case Scenario 

Each of the ammonia storage vessels at the Winyah Generating Station has a capacity of 30,000 gallons. The tanks are administratively controlled via level monitoring and high level alarms to contain a maximum of 82% of the total tank capacity. Therefore, 82% of the total capacity of the tank was considered for the worst-case release scenario (i.e., 24,600 gallons). 



The pounds of ammonia released were calculated using the ammonia storage tank volume and density at storage conditions. Passive mitigation (containment) was not considered in the release scenario since the release was two-phase and was treated as a gaseous release that would not form a pool or be mitigated by an enclosure. 



Since the release is represented as an unmitigated toxic gas, the average release rate was calculated from Equation 3-1 in the OCA Guidance. 



In acc

ordance with 40 CFR ?68.22(b), a wind speed of 1.5 meters per second and an F atmospheric stability class were used for the analysis. As per 40 CFR ?68.22(c), the worst-case scenario was assumed to occur at 99?F and 79% relative humidity, the highest daily maximum temperature and average humidity available from the NOAA for Georgetown Airport in Georgetown, SC for the period of 1/1/2018 through 12/31/2020.



The release was assumed to occur at ground level in accordance with 40 CFR ?68.22(d). Surface roughness was determined to be rural as there are no buildings in the immediate area and the terrain is generally flat and unobstructed in accordance with 40 CFR ?68.22(e).



In accordance with 40 CFR ?68.22(g), since the ammonia in storage is liquified by pressure, the temperature of the ammonia release was considered to be released at the highest daily maximum temperature (99?F) and average relative humidity (79%), based on data for the previous three years appropriate for the site. 



At the toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L, this toxic release and rural topography yielded the following endpoint distance:  



Anhydrous Ammonia - 5.03 miles



The MARPLOT 5.1.1 outputs for the worst-case release scenario detailing the area of release and affected receptors are attached in Section 2. 



Alternative Release Scenario - Process Piping Failure

The alternative release scenario considered that will result in an offsite impact is a failure of a flange connection on process piping for an ammonia storage tank. The size of the piping release was based on the four inch diameter line at bottom of the tank. The pounds released of ammonia was calculated using the density of the ammonia at storage conditions multiplied by the storage volume of the tank, assuming the entire tank empties. Passive mitigation (containment) was not considered in the release scenario. 



In accordance with 40 CFR ?68.22(c) and the RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidance, a wind speed of 3.0 meters per s

econd and a D atmospheric stability class were used for the analysis. The alternate release scenario was assumed to occur at 64?F and 79% relative humidity, the average temperature and average humidity available from the NOAA for Georgetown Airport in Georgetown, SC for the period of January 1, 2018 through December 31, 2020. 



At the toxic endpoint of 0.14 mg/L, this toxic release and rural topography yielded the following endpoint distances:  



Anhydrous Ammonia - 2.73 miles



The MARPLOT 5.1.1 outputs for the alternative case release scenario detailing the area of release and affected receptors are attached in Section 3.



Population and Environmental Receptors

Santee Cooper is required to define offsite impacts from the worst-case and alternate release scenarios. Specifically, the following information is required for each release scenario:



Population:

?    Estimate the population within a circle with its center at the point of the release and a radius determined by the distance to endpoint.  Population shall be estimated to two significant digits.

?    Note the presence of public receptors.



Environmental:

?    List environmental receptors within a circle with its center at the point of the release and a radius determined by the distance to endpoint.



Acceptable data sources for population data include the most recent Census data. In this analysis, the MARPLOT 5.1.1 program is used to estimate potentially affected population within the distance to endpoint and to identify public receptors. MARPLOT 5.1.1 is the most current version of MARPLOT available and contains demographic information from the 2010 Census.  



The presence of institutions (schools, hospitals, prisons), parks and recreational areas, a major commercial, office, and industrial buildings were identified as applicable through the MARPLOT 5.1.1 program and an investigation of the surrounding area via Google Maps.  



Acceptable data sources for environmental receptors include information

provided on local U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) maps or on any data source containing USGS data. The MARPLOT 5.1.1 program contains this USGS data and was used in this analysis to identify environmental receptors within the consequence area. Additional review of USGS maps was conducted to validate data in MARPLOT. 



Toxic Substance Release Impact

The modeled worst-case scenario (WCS) distance to endpoint from an ammonia release is 5.03 miles. Output from MARPLOT 5.1.1 showing the impacted area surrounding the Winyah Generating Station and the estimated affected population is attached in Section 2. At a 5.03-mile radius from the release, MARPLOT 5.1.1 estimates that 9,144 people reside in the area.
